docs.lead_paragraph: Note to teachers: As always, please preview this to make sure it is appropriate for your students. You can find additional teaching resources on systemic racism, policing, protesting and more at the bottom of this post.

headline.main: The Death of Tyre Nichols: A Place for Teenagers to Respond

docs.abstract: “What really happened on that day?” Gwen Carr, Eric Garner’s mother, asked about her son’s death on Staten Island seven years ago.
docs.snippet: “What really happened on that day?” Gwen Carr, Eric Garner’s mother, asked about her son’s death on Staten Island seven years ago.
docs.lead_paragraph: The anguished pleas of Eric Garner as he struggled in a New York City police officer’s chokehold in 2014 galvanized millions, and his last words — “I can’t breathe,” repeated 11 times and captured on video — became a rallying cry for a protest movement demanding that police officers be held accountable.

headline.main: Officers to Testify About Eric Garner’s Death in Long-Delayed Inquiry
headline.print_headline: Police Officers to Testify  About Chokehold Death  In Long-Delayed Inquiry

docs.snippet: Tuesday: Gov. Gavin Newsom and other liberal elected officials are navigating a tricky political situation. Also: More protest updates.

headline.main: A Balancing Act for California’s Democratic Leaders

docs.abstract: From “Black Panther” to “The Hate U Give,” new movies about the fight for black lives deliver powerful fantasies. But can they be truthful?
docs.snippet: From “Black Panther” to “The Hate U Give,” new movies about the fight for black lives deliver powerful fantasies. But can they be truthful?
docs.lead_paragraph: There never was an Officer Andy Landers, but, as conceived by Spike Lee, he’s crudely functional, a villain with a destiny as awful as it is seductive. In “BlacKkKlansman,” Lee’s summer hit based loosely on the true story of Ron Stallworth, a black police officer who infiltrated the Ku Klux Klan in Colorado in the 1970s, Landers is the cretin within, an unreformed racist among Stallworth’s own ranks.

headline.main: The Unreality of Racial Justice Cinema

docs.abstract: For more than 60 years, the premier home for improv comedy was a bastion of whiteness where performers of color were consistently demeaned. Now it is trying to remake itself entirely.
docs.snippet: For more than 60 years, the premier home for improv comedy was a bastion of whiteness where performers of color were consistently demeaned. Now it is trying to remake itself entirely.
docs.lead_paragraph: What happens when a comedy institution realizes that a punchline is not worth a performer’s pain?

headline.main: Second City Is Trying Not to Be Racist. Will It Work This Time?
headline.print_headline: Second City’s Race Problem Is Out in the Open

byline.original: By Melena Ryzik and Jake Malooley

docs.abstract: As a student, Anand Giridharadas asked V.S. Naipaul to dinner on a lark — and, when Naipaul accepted, carried him up three flights of stairs to his apartment. “It was strange and beautiful,” says Giridharadas, whose new book is “The Persuaders,” “to carry the man who had taught me to write.”
docs.snippet: As a student, Anand Giridharadas asked V.S. Naipaul to dinner on a lark — and, when Naipaul accepted, carried him up three flights of stairs to his apartment. “It was strange and beautiful,” says Giridharadas, whose new book is “The Persuaders,” “...
docs.lead_paragraph: Some time ago, I bought a pair of red, can-shaped Italian night stands with tiny curved drawers. I thought they would lend me glamour. Books don’t fit on or in them, however, so I keep a towering pile on the floor, which, between us, is straining my marriage. In the pile now are Joan Didion’s collected nonfiction, James Baldwin’s “Another Country,” Svetlana Alexievich’s “Secondhand Time,” “Inside U.S.A.” by John Gunther, and — my current focus — John Steinbeck’s “The Grapes of Wrath,” which I should have read before but I hadn’t, probably because it was assigned.

headline.main: His Fantasy Literary Dinner Party? He Already Threw It.

docs.abstract: The megadealer David Zwirner has hired Ebony L. Haynes to run a new commercial gallery.
docs.snippet: The megadealer David Zwirner has hired Ebony L. Haynes to run a new commercial gallery.
docs.lead_paragraph: The dealer David Zwirner has hired Ebony L. Haynes, a gallerist who is Black, as the director of a new exhibition program and commercial gallery space in Manhattan, for which she plans to employ an all-Black staff.

headline.main: A New Zwirner Gallery With an All-Black Staff
headline.print_headline: A New David Zwirner Gallery Plans to Have an All-Black Staff

docs.abstract: For many officers, their bodies, minds and lives will never be the same after the attack.
docs.snippet: For many officers, their bodies, minds and lives will never be the same after the attack.
docs.lead_paragraph: On the morning of Jan. 6, Caroline Edwards, a 31-year-old United States Capitol Police officer, was stationed by some stairs on the Capitol grounds when the energy of the crowd in front of her seemed to take on a different shape; it was like that moment when rain suddenly becomes hail. A loud, sour-sounding horn bleated, piercing through the noise of the crowd, whose cries coalesced into an accusatory chant: “U.S.A.! U.S.A.!” Edwards, who is 5-foot-4, tried to make herself look imposing. Behind a row of bike racks, alongside four other officers, she stood in a wide stance, her hands on her hips. A man in front of her whipped off his jacket as if he were getting ready for something, flipped his red MAGA hat backward — and then the rioters were pushing the bike racks forward as the officers pushed back, trying to hold their balance.

headline.main: The Capitol Police and the Scars of Jan. 6

byline.original: By Susan Dominus and Luke Broadwater

docs.abstract: On June 19, 1865, enslaved African Americans in Texas were told they were free. A century and a half later, people across the U.S. continue to celebrate the day, which is now a federal holiday.
docs.snippet: On June 19, 1865, enslaved African Americans in Texas were told they were free. A century and a half later, people across the U.S. continue to celebrate the day, which is now a federal holiday.
docs.lead_paragraph: Juneteenth, an annual commemoration of the end of slavery in the United States after the Civil War, has been celebrated by African Americans since the late 1800s.

headline.main: Juneteenth: The History of a Holiday
headline.print_headline: June 19: A 155-Year-Old Celebration of Freedom and Family

docs.abstract: A San Francisco politician thinks a new bill — named the “CAREN Act” — could be what it takes to get people’s attention, and limit potential harm.
docs.snippet: A San Francisco politician thinks a new bill — named the “CAREN Act” — could be what it takes to get people’s attention, and limit potential harm.
docs.lead_paragraph: The stories showed up in Shamann Walton’s social media feeds with alarming regularity: An eight-year-old selling water to raise money to go to Disneyland. A family barbecuing food on a charcoal grill near Lake Merritt. A man bird watching in Central Park. A woman sitting, leisurely, on a public bench in Manhattan. All of these activities — and several more like them — had been reported to law enforcement, often by strangers passing by.

headline.main: Will It Take a Clever Acronym to Stop Racially Motivated 911 Calls?
